channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Olympus Investigation Shows Ethical Lapses and a Caterer With Clout
item.description: Two years after admitting to accounting fraud, Olympus hired its cafeteria operator to handle a dispute with Chinese customs authorities. Soon after, the case was inexplicably dropped.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN SOBLE
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Olympus campus in Shenzhen, China. The company hired its cafeteria operator to act as a go-between with the government in a thorny customs case.

item.title: Aung San Suu Kyi Has Cataract Surgery, Her Doctor Says
item.description: The operation, which was successful, will be followed by a second later in April for the Burmese leader’s other eye, the doctor said Saturday.
item.dc:creator: WAI MOE
item.media:description: Daw Aung San Suu Kyi underwent successful cataract surgery on Saturday.

item.title: North Korea Says It Successfully Tested Missile Engine
item.description: The announcement Saturday was Pyongyang’s latest claim of success in testing various technologies needed to build an intercontinental ballistic missile.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Before and After the Panama Papers: David Cameron of Britain on Tax Avoidance
item.description: The prime minister has condemned offshore accounts used to avoid taxes, but leaked documents show that his family has profited from an offshore investment fund.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: Johan Van Steen, a Devotee of Photography, Dies in Brussels Attacks
item.description: Mr. Van Steen, 58, was a legal adviser to the Belgian government, but it was his view of the world through the camera’s lens that defined him, his partner says.
item.dc:creator: ELI ROSENBERG
item.media:description: Johan Van Steen was killed in a blast at the Maelbeek subway station in Brussels on March 22.

item.title: Catholics Express Hope and Disappointment Over Pope’s Statement on Families
item.description: Francis’ manifesto, “Amoris Laetitia,” is turning out to be a Rorschach test for members of the Church.
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.dc:creator: LAURIE GOODSTEIN
item.media:credit: Edmund D. Fountain for The New York Times
item.media:description: From left, Cardinal Daniel DiNardo, Archbishop of Galveston-Houston, Tex.; Joseph Kurtz, Archbishop of Louisville, Ky.; and Msgr. Ronny Jenkins at the start of the general session of the U.S. Conference of Catholic Bishops in 2014.

item.title: News Analysis: Rather Than Rules, Pope’s Document Gives License to Adapt
item.description: Rather than dictating policy like a chief executive, Pope Francis effectively devolved power on family issues.
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.dc:creator: JIM YARDLEY
item.media:description: Pope Francis at Easter Mass in St. Peter’s Square last month. He issued an apostolic exhortation on family life on Friday.

item.title: Archbishop of Canterbury Says DNA Test Shows His Father Was Churchill’s Private Secretary
item.description: In frank statements, the Most Rev. Justin Welby, the spiritual leader of 86 million Anglicans, and his mother talked of the shock of discovering the truth in the past month.
item.dc:creator: YONETTE JOSEPH
item.media:description: The Most Rev. Justin Welby after he was installed as the archbishop of Canterbury at Canterbury Cathedral in England in March 2013.

item.title: American Held Captive in Syria Is Released
item.description: An American official said the freed man was Kevin Patrick Dawes, described by some as a freelance photographer and by others as a war-zone adventurer.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE and RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.media:description: Kevin Patrick Dawes, in a 2010 photo posted by the F.B.I. He is said to have been released in Syria after being held for nearly four years.

item.title: More Suspects in Brussels Attacks Arrested in Belgium
item.description: The police in Belgium have detained several men connected to the bombings, the prosecutors’ office said, and one is a fugitive connected to the Paris attacks.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN

item.title: Reporter's Notebook: Musings From the Dalai Lama: Mosquitoes Are Ungrateful, for Starters
item.description: The Dalai Lama spoke to students at the American Embassy School in New Delhi, and a New York Times bureau chief shared a bit of what he said.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY
item.media:description: The Dalai Lama spoke to the students of the American Embassy School in New Delhi on Friday.

item.title: Italy Recalls Envoy to Egypt Over Inquiry Into Student’s Death
item.description: Italy said it was withdrawing its ambassador to protest what it called Cairo’s lack of cooperation in the inquiry into the death of an Italian graduate student.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH

item.title: Once a Bright Spot, Afghan Telecoms Face Unsustainable Losses
item.description: Cellphone providers challenged by the loss of potential customers and hurt by new taxes are trying to expand services and bring more Afghans online.
item.dc:creator: KRISTINA SHEVORY
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Afghan men selling mobile phones at a Kabul market that also sells SIM cards and phone cards.

item.title: Malaysia Panel Calls for Investigation of Former Head of 1MDB Fund
item.description: Members of the state investment fund’s board of directors said they would offer their resignation after a parliamentary committee released its report.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK
item.media:description: The police seizing equipment from the office of 1Malaysia Development Berhad, the state investment fund, in Kuala Lumpur, the capital, last year.

item.title: John Kerry Makes Sudden Trip to Iraq, Affirming U.S. Aid in ISIS Fight
item.description: The visit comes as Iraqi forces have been making notable progress on the battlefield, but the prime minister still faces a political crisis.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: OMAR AL-JAWOSHY

item.title: Opinion: Oh, So Now I’m Bangladeshi?
item.description: Britain is my home. But some of my compatriots have trouble with that.
item.dc:creator: ZIA HAIDER RAHMAN

item.title: Fates Diverging, Afghan and Syrian Migrants Clash in Greece
item.description: A brawl at a detention center and a backlash against migrants reflect growing tension in a country where thousands are trapped while new E.U. rules try to stem migration.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: LIZ ALDERMAN
item.media:description: Migrants at the Greek port of Chios this week.

item.title: Al Qaeda-Linked Group Claims Bangladesh Killing
item.description: A group affiliated with Al Qaeda has claimed responsibility for the killing of a liberal Bangladeshi blogger this week, the SITE monitoring service said.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The Cheating Politicians of Iceland
item.description: First Ashley Madison accounts, now offshore accounts?
item.dc:creator: YRSA SIGURDARDOTTIR
item.media:description: Protesters gathered in front of the Parliament building in Reykjavik, Iceland, on Wednesday.

item.title: Myanmar Releases Dozens of Student Activists From Jail
item.description: Courts ordered that dozens of activists be freed a day after Daw Aung San Suu Kyi announced that addressing the cases of political prisoners was a top priority.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: WAI MOE and RICHARD C. PADDOCK
